newsitem.title: UK: Diabetic mothers still endanger babies - study.
newsitem.headline: Diabetic mothers still endanger babies - study.

text.p: Diabetic mothers have up to a 10-fold risk of having a baby with birth defects and five times the risk of a stillbirth, British doctors reported on Friday.

Although the risks of diabetes in pregnancy are well-known to doctors, the word is evidently not getting out to women with diabetes, Vyvyan Howard, an expert in foetal development at the University of Liverpool, said.
His team studied 462 pregnancies in 355 women with type-one or insulin-dependent diabetes (IDDM) over five years.

Reporting in the British Medical Journal, they said the diabetic women had 10 times the risk of having a baby with a birth defect, and a five-fold risk of stillbirth, as compared to the general population.
Howard said all the mothers in the study knew they had diabetes but many did not act soon enough to make sure their conditions were stabilised.
"Diabetic mothers should take it very seriously and make sure they are in the optimal state before they try to become pregnant," Howard said in a telephone interview.
"We know what to do but it's a matter of raising awareness amongst mothers and potential mothers," he added. "We must try harder."
Howard said scientists still did not fully understand why diabetes caused birth defects.
"It has everything to do with how much energy the embryo is getting," he said.
Although diabetes is common -- IDDM affects more than 13 million people around the world -- the causes are complex.
It causes imbalances in the way fats and sugars are handled by the body. This is crucial in pregnancy.
"Obviously the way that insulin is available and is used has everything to do with the food supply to the foetus," Howard said. "You have to have insulin to get the glucose across to the cell."
If diabetic mothers do not have their blood sugar levels under control, the babies, at a crucial stage of development, suffer.
"A lot of people, by the time they go to see their doctor, they are three months down the line," Howard said.
"That is probably the most critical period -- the time of conception and the first three months of pregnancy."
In a second study published in the journal, Gillian Hawthorne of Hartlepool General Hospital and colleagues also found most diabetic women had their condition poorly controlled at conception.
They found newborn babies of women with IDDM had a mortality rate 15 times higher than normal and four times the rate of birth defects.
"Diabetic pregnancy remains a high-risk state," they concluded.
